instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
Not much liquid residue on the board. Seems like came in most near display control connector of course. 

Some noticeable stuff in near <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> at <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7100</CAPACITOR>. on other side of board around one side of <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>. Customer noted display started discoloring in one corner before it was shut down.

PPBUS G3H is 13V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> shows voltage going to zero. Diode here to ground is .295V


From what I've seen here in forums this board CPU often gets overvoltage w/liquid damage. I don't want to waste a lot of time on this as it if it is low probability fix.

SOme quick things to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
Any liquid sign around pins 1 & 43 of J8500?
Compare diode mode readings on pins 1 & 3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
J8500 looks clean on board and in cable connector. No sign of liquid or shorting on pins. Another shop tried drying it out for customer. They must've been in the mac because one of the cable pull tabs was missing. So I don't know if they cleaned the board connectors at all. I don't think so or I would think they would have seen residue in spots on the board.

Pin 1 diode= 0.264V
Pin 3 diode= 0.268V

Here is a summary of areas where there was liquid residue:
C/<RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>/1
<CHIP>U7220</CHIP>
<CAPACITOR>C7210</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C8006</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: Liquid signs on CPU power supply is not good at all; probably dead CPU now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: Yeah... that and the fact that the damn display controller is right in the direct path of potential liquid, I'm wondering if the display is any good either. SO keyboard is 99% chance of being toast. SOunds like CPU is 75% or more of being dead, any way to get a guess on display?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: Actual LCD assembly must be tested with known good board, if you want to know its state...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
I gave it one last poke around and noticed good voltage on
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
PUt it back in mac with one USB-C, display, one speaker and keyboard connected and get fan spin high. No display and no chime, no external display. If CPU fried still common to see basics work, correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> shows voltage going to zero.
----------------------------
noticed good voltage on
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> "
What happened?
Do you get VCORE now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
Not sure what happened... I had cleaned those areas... but thought had taken readings since cleaning. 

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SO_VCORE1</SIGNAL>= 5.16V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: VCORE is the generic name for main CPU power rail; <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> in this case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: When 1st powered on VCORE is 1.1V about 5secs after fans kick in (~10 seconds after power), it drops to 0.62V, at about 15secs from power on it pops to 1.1V but then immediately back to 0.62V and fans pick up speed to full on. It then holds at 0.62V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
0.62V looks good and mentioned changes are normal.
Seems that board is booting; check for USB activity...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: It will supply power to usb-c with charger plugged in but as example flash drive light stays solid only.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
Voltage reactions on VCORE look like board boots.
Compare the other coils voltages with working board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: dah. don't have another working board for this to compare to...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: Apart of AXG (GFX), you should get all other voltages for DDR, PCH, CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: I realized the reason this board later started was because the trackpad was unplugged. Doesn't start with trackpad plugged in. Does trackpad need to be good for this to POST/boot? I don't currently have another trackpad to try for this model, and had kind of thought this might be a lost cause but thought I'd give it one more go.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: Check what happens disconnecting keyboard only (trackpad connected).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message: No it only seems to start with trackpad disconnected. keyboard/touch bar  can be connected or not. Touchbar doesn't show any activity, no usb activity detected. If board starts and I plug trackpad in after it started it will shut itself off after 30 plus seconds, and will start again as soon as I unplug the trackpad again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings (J4501) with good board.
Check all <SIGNAL>TPAD_SPI</SIGNAL> resistors.

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is steady 3V with track√†d connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
I don't. have a good board to compare to unfortunately. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is steady 3V w TrackPad connected. It now starts with TP connected most of the time although one fan seems to be a bit wonky or slower than the other with the TPad connected. I tried reflashing the firmware a couple of times. When plugged into external display the display goes black. USB-C to external drive still not showing any data activity. With speaker plugged in and charger, I hear the chirp related to power from the speaker. CPU gets warm. It really does seem like it is trying to boot or partially booting.

Wondering if I should try SMC if I can source one? I had mostly written this one off but when I get time, I try a few things as it seems like there COULD be hope for this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Boot, liquid damaged
threads.message:
Liquid spill on these new boards is a nightmare.
So many small components and data lines density inside board high too.
